=== Contributions ===
* 2005-2010 - Ran the <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/LaptopTestingTeam/Old/DellInspiron510m|LaptopTesting page for my laptop]]</nowiki>, testing betas, RCs and releases of Breezy, Dapper, Edgy, Feisty, Gutsy, Hardy, Intrepid, Jaunty and Karmic, noting regressions and filing bugs accordingly. 
* 2005-2010 - <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/LaptopTestingTeam/Old/DellInspiron510m#Benchmarks|Benchmarking]]</nowiki> of each release against each other and the pre-installed Windows XP (Grub -> Login; Shutdown -> Power-off; Suspend to RAM (sleep); Resume from RAM (wake); Suspend to HD (hibernate); and Resume from HD), identifying bugs e.g. <nowiki>[[https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/reiserfsprogs/+bug/67301|Bug #67301]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux-source-2.6.20/+bug/61407|Bug #61407]]</nowiki>
* 2006 - Created <nowiki>[[GnomePowerManagerInhibitSpec]]</nowiki>, <nowiki>[[InhibitingGnomeScreensaver]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[GnomePowerManagerInactiveSleep]]</nowiki> and advocated (identifying relevant projects and filing bugs etc) that more Ubuntu projects used these to prevent the screensaver coming on/the machine suspending when they should not. 
* 2008? - Part of the <nowiki>[[PDATeam]]</nowiki>, testing Ubuntu with Palm Pilots!
* 2005-Today: <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/~aaron-whitehouse/+reportedbugs|Filed]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/~aaron-whitehouse/+commentedbugs|commented on]]</nowiki> a reasonable number of Launchpad (and upstream) bugs, receiving credit for <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/RaringRingtail/ReleaseNotes/Credits/BugReporters?highlight=(Aaron%20Whitehouse)|Raring]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/SaucySalamander/ReleaseNotes/Credits/BugReporters?highlight=(Aaron%20Whitehouse)|Saucy]]</nowiki>.
* 2015-Today: Member of the <nowiki>[[https://launchpad.net/~duplicity-team/+members|development team]]</nowiki> for <nowiki>[[https://gitlab.com/duplicity/duplicity|duplicity]]</nowiki>, Ubuntu's default "Backups" application. Work items particularly related to Ubuntu were work on: 
** <nowiki>[[https://blueprints.launchpad.net/duplicity/+spec/python3|converting Duplicity to Python 3]]</nowiki> as part of removing Python 2 from the Ubuntu desktop images
** creating GitLab CI testing against <nowiki>[[https://gitlab.com/duplicity/duplicity/-/merge_requests/7|16.04]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[https://gitlab.com/duplicity/duplicity/-/merge_requests/3|Ubuntu 18.04]]</nowiki>
** <nowiki>[[https://gitlab.com/duplicity/duplicity/-/commit/2f4a152769a9b06a25a3b9b42956c308ee0c0aad|created the original]]</nowiki> duplicity snap and our original <nowiki>[[https://snapcraft.io/duplicity|Snap Store page]]</nowiki> (now part of our CI/CD).
* 2021 - onwards:
** As part of my role at Canonical, worked to improve Ubuntu across the board on Public Clouds, with a particular interest in ensuring Public Cloud systems management tooling and similar work as well as possible on Ubuntu instances. 
** Created <nowiki>[[https://github.com/Hooloovoo/list-universe|list-universe]]</nowiki>, a simple script to list and count the packages that were installed from Ubuntu's Universe repository.
** Created <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/tutorials/purchasing-and-applying-16-04-esm-from-the-azure-marketplace|Ubuntu tutorial for Azure users to apply ESM to their 16.04 VMs]]</nowiki>
** Created <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/tutorials/using-azure-ad-to-manage-ssh-logins-to-ubuntu|Ubuntu tutorial on using Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) to manage SSH logins for Ubuntu virtual machines on Azure]]</nowiki>
** Created <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/tutorials/create-a-hardened-ubuntu-pro-18-04-lts-shared-image-with-azure-image-builder#1-overview|tutorial on creating a hardened "golden" image of Ubuntu using Azure Image Builder]]</nowiki>
** Created <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/tutorials/testing-the-self-healing-of-zfs-on-ubuntu#1-overview|tutorial on the self-healing of ZFS on Ubuntu 20.04]]</nowiki>
** Regular calls with significant users of Ubuntu on Public Clouds (normally users of free Ubuntu offerings), advising how they can use Ubuntu more effectively.
** Presented <nowiki>[[https://www.brighttalk.com/webcast/6793/538507|a webinar giving practical tips on Ubuntu and open-source supply chain security for Azure users]]</nowiki> as part of Microsoft Germany's OSS series.
** Co-presented <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/engage/cloud-cost-optimisation-best-practices|Cloud cost optimisation best practices]]</nowiki>, giving practical tips on how Ubuntu users on Public Clouds could reduce their costs.
** Added Prometheus metric exporters to <nowiki>[[https://github.com/jimsalterjrs/sanoid/pull/761|Sanoid]]</nowiki> now that Ubuntu has chosen Prometheus as part of the Charmed Observability Stack.
** <nowiki>[[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nnvsletLWNk|Presented a Lightboard presentation]]</nowiki> and wrote <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/blog/securing-open-source-software-dependencies-in-the-public-cloud|a blog]]</nowiki> on securing open source software dependencies in the public cloud.
** Co-wrote a three-part blog series with John Chittum on how to ensure security and stability in cloud instances: <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/blog/ubuntu-updates-releases-and-repositories-explained|part 1]]</nowiki>, <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/blog/ubuntu-updates-best-practices-for-updating-your-instance|part 2]]</nowiki> and <nowiki>[[https://ubuntu.com/blog/securing-multiple-ubuntu-instances-while-maximising-uptime|part 3]]</nowiki>.

=== Future Goals/Ongoing Work ===

* Assistance, tutorials and guidance to Ubuntu users, particularly those on Public Clouds.
* Contribution to technical specifications of Ubuntu tools that make it easier to integrate external systems management tooling with Ubuntu instances.
* Continued contribution to duplicity that helps Ubuntu users, particularly on backwards compatibility testing for Ubuntu releases.
* I have been running a duplicity-based backup setup across multiple machines for many years and have recently converted this to a ZFS/snapshots/Sanoid/offsite Raspberry Pi/Nebula solution, all based on Ubuntu. I would like to document this as guidance for others with the same objectives.
